title: invokeRight
body:
``` js
let array = [1,2,3]

// before
_(array)
  .forEachRight (_) => _.method()
  .value()

// after
_(array)
  .invokeRight 'method'
  .value()
```

title: Add `_.zipWith`.

title: zipWith, is this something people might want?
Enhancement proposal : Improve lazy evaluation
body:
Hello, 

I have an idea of a useful feature for lodash. Sometimes we have a lot of data and we want to make operations on it (map) and then find any one of them who satisfy some predicate (find). But I remarked that the lazy evaluation is not lazy at all (maybe I'm not using it correctly). I think when we do map followed by a find (or any) we should check the predicate as soon as we have one value available. Currently in lodash we wait for the map to be finished for all values. 

In a more formal we we can say that

```
a.map(f).find(p)  = a.find(f°p) 
```

I know this is true only if we assume that f does not produce any side-effects (maybe it is the reason why it is not implemented already) but the second one is much faster.

Do you think it would be a good idea ?

I didn't dive into the code yet but I think it would be easy. (I assume the chaining of operations are implemented using a stack of operations that are only called when value() is called). We just need to check when value() is called if such a pattern happens and replace the operations in the stack.

I know some functional languages already do this kind of optimization (scala which has also the problem with side-effects).

Best regards

title: Sort by all iteratees
body:
(I know this is the wrong file but I'm on a different computer :p)

Anyway @jdalton how do you feel about `sortByAll` and `sortByOrder` accepting more than just properties. I have a couple use cases for this namely multi column sorts with different importance factors.

As a bonus this should have deep support yeah?!!!

title: Feature: Deep freeze, immutable "mutators"
body: I'm not sure what is the stated goal of Lodash, but it would be nice to have a deep freezing capability of objects. `Object.freeze` freezes the object properties, not their contents. There could be other immutable mutator functions which may be useful to implement. E.g. to modify a frozen object one creates a clone, then modifies it, and freezes again.

title: Add `_.replaceAll`
Spread Last Parameter
Supporting ES6 Map
body:
Did a bit of searching and didn't see related tickets right away, so I wanted to check if there were any plans to support iterating structures like ES6 `Map` or I guess more generally ES6 iterables:

``` js
var m = new Map([['a', 1], ['b', 2]])

_.forEach(m, (val, key) => {
  console.log(val) // 1, 2
})
```

This would be great because maps eliminate weird edge cases of treating an object like map (among other things). I'm currently using other libraries which support unified iteration between object/map but it'd be great if this were a case lodash could support.

If performance is a concern, perhaps it could be opt-in as a superset of collection?

``` js
import forEach from 'lodash/iteration/forEach'
```

title: Generator support
body:
I discovered that many (all?) functions are generator-incompatible.
For example `lodash.take(5, fibonacci())` returns `[]` because

Any plans to update that?

title: Reduce return value on empty array
body:
I would definitely expect `_.reduce([], true)` to return `true` but it returns `undefined` instead.

As mentionned in the doc:

> [accumulator](*): The initial value.
> (*): Returns the accumulated value.

So the looping behavior went on 0 time, but the initial value of the accumulator should be returned, shouldn't it?

If that's on purpose, could I get some explanation on why?

title: handling of special chars in i.e. startCase
_.removeFirst / _.removeLast in addition to _.remove
body:
Title's pretty self-explanatory. Trying to replace the broken code from #1113, and surprised to find that this functionality isn't explicitly exposed by Lodash.

As `_.remove(array, predicate)`, except it ceases iteration on the first truthy-result, removes that result, and returns it (leaving remaining elements of the array untested / untouched.)

title: Note in iterator methods whether or not the iterator can mutate the collection
body:
I'm running into this issue today:

```
_(collection).find (item, index)->
   collection.splice(index, 0) if item.predicate()
```

After updating Lodash through quite a few versions (my own fault for letting it lag behind, but hey.), the code of that form ceased working. I've discovered that that `find()` is now returning an undefined result, presumably because it tries to access the element by index _after_ my iterator function mutates the collection.

Looking through the documentation, I can find no mention of mutating iterators. If this approach is more performant, I'm fine with it; but it should probably be mentioned in the documentation which Lodash function-arguments are expected to be pure, and which can mutate the environment Lodash operates in.

title: In addition to explicitly-chainable wrappers, offer explicitly-unchainable ones.
body:
I use CoffeeScript (yes, still, in 2015. :P) A _huge_ reason I loved CoffeeScript was how beautiful CoffeeScript's implicit indentation and short function syntax is when combined with many of the Lodash tools:

```
_(@content).remove (entry)->
   return false if accessor? and entry.accessor != accessor
   _(entry.masks).remove (m)-> m.conflictsWith mask
   return true if entry.masks.length == 0
```

Unfortunately, with Lodash 3.0.0's lazy chains, a huge quantity of my code now breaks. The explicit fix would be to replace _all_ of my CoffeeScript using Lodash with something more like the following:

```
_(@content).remove((entry)->
   return false if accessor? and entry.accessor != accessor
   _(entry.masks).remove((m)-> m.conflictsWith mask).commit()
   return true if entry.masks.length == 0
).commit()
```

I find this a hell of a lot uglier (and this is a simple example, with only two nested Lodash iterators; I've got situations where several happen _on one line_!). I understand the rationale for the lazy-by-default / chain-by-default; but in addition to the existing `_.chain()` (which explicitly _enables_ method-chaining), I'd like to see something like `_.just()` that explicitly disables chaining on the wrapped object (and a correspondingly `_.proto.just()` to explicitly disable chaining on a pre-existing wrapped object).

With that, I could do something like the following:

```
__ = _.just

func = ->
   __(object).iterator (ele)-> maipulate ele
```

… and boom, all the beauty of CoffeeScript's implicit functions and implicit returns is restored to me.

title: Downloading v3.6.0-amd
body:
Not sure if I'm doing something wrong I am trying to download the AMD version of lodash, I'm expecting to get access to all of the individual lodash helpers individually except within my `bower_components` folder I am getting a lodash folder with `lodash.js` containing the entire thing? Am I doing something wrong?

In my bower.json file I have:

```
"dependencies": {
    "lodash": "~3.6.0-amd"
  }
```

bower output:

```
bower lodash#~3.6.0-amd     not-cached git://github.com/lodash/lodash.git#~3.6.0-amd
bower lodash#~3.6.0-amd        resolve git://github.com/lodash/lodash.git#~3.6.0-amd
bower lodash#~3.6.0-amd       download https://github.com/lodash/lodash/archive/3.6.0.tar.gz
bower lodash#~3.6.0-amd        extract archive.tar.gz
bower lodash#~3.6.0-amd       resolved git://github.com/lodash/lodash.git#3.6.0
bower lodash#~3.6.0-amd        install lodash#3.6.0
```

Thanks in advanced

title: Union in chained calls
_.reduce on a chain returns the output, not a wrapped object.
body:
I was surprised to learn 

``` js
_([1,2,3]).reduce(function(out, i){ return out += i }, 0) // returns 6
```

I was expecting a wrapped lodash object. Is this a bug? If not, maybe the bug is that that docs should state that `.reduce` commits a chain?

title: Minor change to `once` to avoid extra var swap
body:
The way `once` uses `before` causes the inputs to always be swapped as `before` expects them in a different order.

Here is the [before definition](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.src.js#L7452) and the [once usage](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.src.js#L8073) for a quick reference.

title: _.matches with function properties
body:
_.matches and family members like _.where seem to ignore properties whose values are functions. This is consistent, I think, with the documentation ("This method supports comparing arrays, booleans, Date objects, numbers, Object objects, regexes, and strings.") suggesting it may be intended behavior. Then again, even the "name" property gets ignored, so it doesn't seem to compare functions as regular objects either.

I don't know how much importance is given to consistency between Lodash methods and their analogs in Underscore -- so this may be irrelevant -- but I was surprised to find _.where gave such different results.

If it is a deliberate design decision, what's the reasoning behind it?

title: Add _.ordinalize(integer) function
body:
Would you guys be interested in an ordinalize funtion for numbers to coerce them to the readable string?

I've found a really simple implementation we could copy
http://ecommerce.shopify.com/c/ecommerce-design/t/ordinal-number-in-javascript-1st-2nd-3rd-4th-29259

this would allow the following:

```
_.ordinalize(3) // => "3rd"
_.ordinalize(726) // => "726th"
//etc
```

title: Make `_.inRange` swap `start` and `end` when `start` is greater than `end`.
body:
Hi,

`_.inRange(n, [start=0], end)` seems to be not working with negative numbers.

title: Support filtering with `assign()`
body: I've just run into an interesting use case where I want to use `assign(objA, objB)` but I want to be able to provide a whitelist of properties that are allowed to be assigned to `objA` from `objB` (or any other objects). Obviously I can manually filter each object before passing it to `assign`, but it'd be awesome if I could just pass an option or something with a list of allowed properties that will be assigned to `objA`, ignoring any properties that aren't in the list. Maybe `assign` could support a `filter` option or somehow take advantage of the `customizer` function to simply ignore certain properties.

title: _.isDefined()
body:
In our code base we had a lot of instances of `typeof variable === 'undefined'` which we could replace with `if (_.isUndefined(variable))`.

But we had even more instances of `typeof variable !== 'undefined'` which ended up looking like `if (!_.isUndefined(variable))` and it reads like "if variable is not undefined" which is kinda weird.

I want to propose a `_.isDefined()` function which is the opposite of `_.isUndefined()` to make the code more readable.

Sidenot: comparing string inequality is arguably faster than string equality since the processor doesn't have to swipe the whole string to compute the result.

title: Apply 'xor' to object
Description of range() should be improved
body:
What I read for 3.6.0 for _.range: "_Creates an array of numbers (positive and/or negative) progressing from start up to, but not including, end. If end is not specified it is set to start with start then set to 0. If start is less than end a zero-length range is created unless a negative step is specified._"
But:
- end is not marked as optional. Perhaps the signature should be: `_.range([start=0, [end=start, [step=1]]])`
- "_If start is less than end_" should be "if end is than or equal to start".

title: Adding _.resultDeep() to resolve #1060, #700, et al.
body:
I saw that #1060 had lost momentum so thought I'd revive it with a PR.

I choose to create a new `_.resultDeep()` since the functionality seemed to me like an extension of what `_.result()` does. Not sure if anyone has strong feelings about the naming or arguments but at least now we have some code in front of us to hash this out.

I'm also hoping for suggestions to tidy up the `dropRight()` + `last()` combo. I had originally used a for-loop but ended up trading the performance gains for fewer bytes and better maintainability. Thoughts?

title: Documentation: "T" icons do nothing
body: As mentioned in [#1076](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/1076#issuecomment-86063939), the "T" links in the documentation do not work. Right now there are 207 instances of `Ⓣ` in the markup. None of those links work because there is no element with an `id` attribute of `array`. Additionally, it doesn't make sense for them to all be the same link. I'm assuming something is just going wrong in the documentation generation step. This is a useful feature generally, but of even more benefit on mobile. Three things are needed to fix this: - each TOC item needs an `id` attribute (not including the aliases) - each "T" link needs to change the `href` attribute from `#array` to the above-mentioned `id` values - (optionally) some kind of visual affordance to signify the jump I mocked up [an example of how this could work](http://lodash-docs-work.s3-website-us-east-1.amazonaws.com/docs-toc/). I added the yellow highlight just to indicate what happened. I tested in Firefox, Chrome, and Safari. _(Seriously, tell me to stop if these are coming too fast. Your roadmap doesn't mention documentation right now, so I don't want to take anyone off track. I love lodash. You guys are making my job so much better. Thank you.)_

title: Question about _.remove index arg behavior
body:
``` javascript
var x = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
_.remove(x, function (e, i, a) {
    console.log(e, i, a); return i % 2 === 0;
}); //=> [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
x//=> 0
```

Logs:

```
0 0 [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
1 0 [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
2 0 [2, 3, 4, 5]
3 0 [3, 4, 5]
4 0 [4, 5]
5 0 [5]
```

Looking at the source, one sees that `_.remove` splices the array/decrements index as it removes elements, so that in the above case index will always be 0. Was there a reason this behavior was chosen (I don't see a test case which is immediately relevant, so perhaps it's an edge case)? This behavior can be changed by iterating backwards instead of forwards, I believe. Either way, perhaps could use some documentation - would be happy to submit a PR.

title: _.head() should be aliased to _.take(), not _.first()
body:
Expected behavior: `head([1, 2, 3], 2) -> [1, 2]`
Current behavior: `head([1, 2, 3], 2) -> [1, 2, 3]`

`_.head()` was initially aliased to `_.first()` when `_.first()` had more than one argument. Since `first()` now takes only one argument, `_.head()` should probably alias to `_.take()` instead.

In fact, why not alias `_.first()` to `_.take()`?

title: Documentation: display if a function is chainable or not
body:
Hi

In the documentation each function currently has # Ⓢ Ⓣ Ⓝ links.

I suggest adding a Ⓒ indicating that the function is chainable. Clicking on this symbol could point to the ___ anchor.

A Ⓕ could be used for function like _.filter supporting shortcut fusion.

title: Documentation: back button broken on anchor usage (desktop)
body:
_(Let me know if the documentation things I'm bringing up are getting too much.)_

In trying to mock up some changes to the presentation of `iteratee` and `predicate` information, I wanted to address something that's been driving me up the wall:  On desktop, when you are reading one part of the documentation and then click a link to another function, you can't use the Back button to return to what you were just reading.

**Example:** [go here](https://lodash.com/docs#forEach), click on the link in the function's description to `_.forIn` or `_.forOwn` and then click Back.  Nothing happens.  This presents for me on Firefox, Chrome, Safari, and IE 10.  Due to the media queries present, this does not present on mobile, or likely any viewport narrower than 960px.

This breaks normal browser behavior and can be frustrating to someone just learning lodash.  You see a link, try to figure out what it means, then go ba...wait...what was I looking at again?  Expected behavior would be something like clicking an inline link to a footnote on Wikipedia, then returning to your place with the Back button.

The underlying problem is that (on desktop) the `doc-container` is a scrolling div, which the browser can't reset the position of; I'm assuming that it can only reset the position of `body` when going back.  I would like to propose some CSS to fix this that handles the markup in a way that respects the semantics of the page while laying out `position` differently.

[See here for a live example](http://lodash-docs-work.s3-website-us-east-1.amazonaws.com/docs/) of the proposed fix.  The actual [changed CSS file is here](http://lodash-docs-work.s3-website-us-east-1.amazonaws.com/_css/main.css).  You will find four references to `@venning` in the comments.  I can explain the thinking for those changes a little more if you'd like, but this is already a lot of prose for a small issue.

There should be no visual difference in this fix when rendered, except that this positions the main scrollbar a little more naturally across the entire height of the page instead of being a little cut off at the top; "naturally" being a personal preference.  Also, there will be purple blur under the chrome when scrolling in Safari but, again, that should feel natural.

I feel like I'm missing some edge case, so let me know if anything looks wonky.

title: The wrapper Array methods push, unshift, ... not work.
Add possibility to pass equality tester to _.difference
body: There is no possibility to compute difference of arrays of objects (no chance to override `===` operator). It would be just great to have a way to pass equality tester (function) to `_.difference` in order to define which objects are equal in context of their content.

title: _.extend not modifying parameter
body:
Hello, I'm trying to migrate my code from underscore to lodash and get stuck with the following:

```
var Animal = function(){
this.init();...
}
_(Animal.prototype).extend({init:function(){...}})

```

with underscore this works but not with lodash . error is in this.init() - 'undefined is not a function'. 
Rewriting it like this seems to fix it :

```
Animal.prototype = _.extend(Animal.prototype, {init:function(){...}})
```

Unfortunately rewriting is not in my short-term plans. 

Is this an issue ?- or is this a fact of life? It is a requirement of lodash to fully emulate underscore API ? 

Thanks in advance - any workaround for this is very appreciated and sorry if this is not an issue. :)

P/D: I also test this in 'compat' mode - this is running 'lodash compat'  but without luck.
P/D: this behavior is reproducible in older (1.5) and latest (1.8) underscore versions

title: _.and, _.or, and _.not for combining predicates?
Documentation: predicate and iteratee mixed up
body:
(Referencing #1049, this is something that I encountered as well.)

After noticing a mix of `iteratee` parameters with `predicate` descriptions, I repurposed the documentation checker to look for offending descriptions.  The following all take `iteratee` as a parameter but reference `predicate` in their descriptions:
- [`_.uniq`](https://lodash.com/docs#uniq)
- [`_.countBy`](https://lodash.com/docs#countBy)
- [`_.groupBy`](https://lodash.com/docs#groupBy)
- [`_.indexBy`](https://lodash.com/docs#indexBy)
- [`_.map`](https://lodash.com/docs#map)

The current documentation on lodash.com contains more examples of this than those five, but the current codebase seems to have fixed all but these five.  There are no examples of the opposite problem (`predicate` for `iteratee`).  [Script for checking this here](https://gist.github.com/venning/55173b5e5f80aea39995).

_I noticed the use of `@param-` to hide params that are used only for functional purposes.  Doctrine does not parse them correctly, which is probably the point.  There are no `iteratee` or `predicate` params hidden this way, as far as I can tell.  If there are other subtleties to the documentation that affect this, I missed them._

---

Additionally, I had a similar idea to @octref's regarding [pulling out the verbatim descriptions](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/1049#issuecomment-79081841) of `iteratee`, `predicate`, etc and replacing them with references describing how to use them.  My tendency when reading the docs is to assume that the lines are repeated because they are subtly different between individual functions, with some sort of function-specific nuance.  That means I read them each time, which is slow and, assuming they are in face identical, unnecessary.  I can mock up an example or two of how to represent this differently, if there's desire.

title: deburr not working for certain strings
body:
I am trying to fix some filenames that have non-standard characters and I thought that `deburr` was going to be a big help. However, it doesn't have any effect on certain strings, i.e. (copy and pasted from a filename giving me trouble):
Etchéa Art Déco

Is it because this string is encoded using something other than Latin-1? How would I be able to tell that?

title: Pass templateSettings when calling the template method
body:
Sometimes templateSettings are good, but most of the time is better if you send the templateSettings when you call the template function. For example it should be like this:

``` js
_.template('hello {{ user }}!', { 'interpolate': /{{([\s\S]+?)}}/g });
```

I understand that you want an easy to use lib, but this allow to create bugs. Even using your technique, if the same file needs the template function but one expect the default and the 2nd will change the settings, it will mess up the first one.

title: _.chain( values )  cannot  call many chain method
dicussion: .matches works but makes lodash very messy conceptually
body:
Hey, I've noticed there are some bugs related to the .matches behaviour (#892, #899, #909, #937,  #939, #945 ). It does feel very weird. It works but makes lodash very messy conceptually. It seems that .matches is really .matchesOwnProperties, just with a misleading name and description (_"returns true for elements that have the properties of the given object"_ should probably be something like _"returns true for elements that have the properties of the given object as their own, non-inherited properties"_). It might be the most natural way to match objects (although opinions will probably vary) but certainly not the most general. It's a bit like naming a function .isAnimal while it only works for mammals. This confusion is amplified by the fact that there's .matchesProperty which is more specific than .matches in one aspect (finds only a single property) but more general in that it looks for both own and inherited properties. 

This also means that suddenly most examples only show part of the story (they all use own properties where there's little difference), and to show how a function behaves would require to show cases where both types of properties (own and inherited) are defined. Again, this shows that the use of lodash got much more complex, and being able to just read an example and know what a function does was a great thing, especially for people who are new to it. 

On top of this before someone uses something like find he needs to understand much more about lodash implementation and also make sure any object he or she might be looking for is not using inheritance (which is ok in case they are created by you, but in fact requires checking the internals of any library you might be getting objects from (at least by hasOwnProperty)). So even if someone knows the difference between .matches and .matchesProperty going from searching by a single property to matching by 2 is suddenly a whole big thing, and even when searching by a single property the difference between these two is a debugging nightmare waiting to happen:
`_.result(_.find(users, 'active', false), 'user');`
`_.result(_.find(users, {'active': false}), 'user');`

title: Fixed errors in documentation examples for _.trim, _.matchesProperty, & ...
body: This is in reference to issue #1065

title: Errors in documentation examples
body:
After noticing an error in one of the **documentation examples**, I ran them all through a script and found a few more.  There are small errors in three examples that I can fix:
- [the example for **`_.trim`**](https://lodash.com/docs#trim) is missing a single-quote
- [the example for **`_.matchesProperty`**](https://lodash.com/docs#matchesProperty) is using the wrong starting `users` object to produce the stated result
- [the example for **`_.property`**](https://lodash.com/docs#property) is missing a single-quote

There are also errors in four more examples that I'm not sure exactly how to fix:
- [the example for **`_.runInContext`**](https://lodash.com/docs#runInContext) assumes that `_.add` doesn't exist by default, which is no longer true as of v3.4.0; so the example not only makes less sense, it also shows `lodash.isFunction(lodash.add);` returning `false` when it will now return `true` in the current version; I'm not sure what would make a better example
- [the example for **`_.thru`**](https://lodash.com/docs#thru) errors when `_.last()` returns a `Number` and then tries to call the `thru` method of that `Number`; I have no idea what you're trying to do with that example, so I have no suggestions on how to correct it
- [the example for **`_.forEachRight`**](https://lodash.com/docs#forEachRight) states that it "returns the array", but it actually returns a concatenation of the array's contents care of `Array.prototype.join`; this is probably a copy-and-paste from `_.forEach` where the final chained call is to `_#value`; not sure if you'd rather change it back to `_#value` or fix the result description
- [the example for **`_.escapeRegExp`**](https://lodash.com/docs#escapeRegExp) does not show _slashes_ being escaped, which is matched by the description which also does not list _slashes_ as being escaped; but [the codebase shows](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.src.js#L120) _slash_ being part of `reRegExpChars`; the documentation links to this [article on `RegExp` characters](http://www.regular-expressions.info/characters.html#special) which does not list _slash_ as special; either the documentation and example need to show _slash_ as being escaped or the code needs to remove _slash_ from the characters that are escaped

My assumption is that you are using `lodash.src.js` for the codebase and deriving documentation from that.  If that's the case, I'll submit a pull request for the first three fixes and either let you fix the next four or I'll submit a pull request for those on your suggestion on which way you'd like to fix them.

_(I should state that I've never submitted a pull request for an open source project before, so I may be going about this haphazardly.)_

title: Allow callback for step parameter in _.range
Why can't _.fill populate an empty array?
body:
After some trial and error, I understand how `_.fill` works. However, I initially thought I'd be able to do something like `_.fill([], 'blah', 0, 5)` to get `['blah', 'blah', 'blah', 'blah', 'blah']`. Is there some reason this _can't_ work? Or maybe a `_.populate` to create an array of default values? I understand what `fill` does, but not _why_ it only does that. Is there a technical (or semantic) reason that `_.fill` can't populate non-existent indices?

(FWIW, `_.fill([0, 0, 0], 'blah', 0, 5)` functions similarly. It returns `['blah', 'blah', 'blah']` rather than `['blah', 'blah', 'blah', 'blah']`.)

title: exposed createAggregator as _.createAggregator
_.merge adds extra element when merging nesting array into object
body: `_.merge({set:{}}, {set:[]})` creates a set array with length of 1, `{set:[0:undefined]}`. I'm assuming it should return `{set:{}}` similar to how `_.merge({}, [])` just returns `{}`.

title: Add function to get nested property value
body:
The only thing I really miss from lodash is the `get` function that MOUT implements to get nested property value, returning `undefined` if it doesn't exist.

MOUT API Documentation: http://moutjs.com/docs/latest/object.html#get

Would it be possible to implement a similar function for lodash?

title: fix _.zipObject docs to more clearly demonstrate it as _.pairs' inverse
body: I spent a while today attempting to look for a method that was effectively the inverse of `_.pairs`. Although the docs do point out that `_.zipObject` does this, it's hard to find with Ctrl+F and there are no actual examples of it which is what I usually scan through when looking for things. This just clears that up. :)

title: Allocate proper size
body:
Since we're putting `rest` at `start` index, `array.length = {start + 1}`.

(submitted a CLA on 2015-03-15 17:13:29)

body:
related to #1048 . I've signed the CLA. (Pull #956 )
Please point out any errors. I'll check them and make fixes asap.

title: Browserify bundle with require("lodash") crashes the chrome remote debugger
body:
Browserify bundle with require("lodash") crashes the chrome remote debugger

using lodash 3.3.0 and 3.5.0

e.g. 

```
// install lodash
npm install lodash

//in main.js
var lo = require("lodash")

// on the command line
browserify main.js --outfile bundle.js

//in index.html
<script type="text/javascript" src="bundle.js"></script>
```

Next attach an android device via usb and begin remote debugging
the debugger will crash after a second or two.

I have tried many other npm modules with the method and they all seem to work fine in the remote debugger.

As a side note using webpack instead of browserify seems to work fine.

title: How to include in project compiled with Closure Compiler?
body:
If I understand correctly, to maximize the benefits of Closure Compiler's dead code removal, I should compile lodash together with my own code, so that the compiler knows which lodash functions to keep around. (I know I can make a custom build of lodash with only the needed functions, but I'm hoping to let the compiler keep track of them.) Is this possible?

I'm assuming that lodash supports the Closure Compiler because the lodash-cli tool uses the Closure Compiler on lodash.

I tried concatenating the lodash.js file from the github release to my code and running the compiler on that, and the compiler complained about undeclared variable "module" in "var freeModule = objectTypes[typeof module] && module && !module.nodeType && module;". (It may be relevant that I run the compiler with --warning_level=VERBOSE.) I could try adding "module" as an extern, but I thought I'd ask for an "official" solution before trying hacks.

title: `sortBy`, `max`, `min` doc inconsistency
body:
The function signature uses `iteratee` but the description uses `predicate`. 

Possible to confuse some people.

In `max`, we even have mixed use of `iteratee` and `predicate` within just the function description

`_.max(collection, [iteratee], [thisArg])`

> Gets the maximum value of collection. If collection is empty or falsey -Infinity is returned. If an iteratee function is provided it is invoked for each value in collection to generate the criterion by which the value is ranked. The **iteratee** is bound to thisArg and invoked with three arguments; (value, index, collection). 
> 
> If a property name is provided for **predicate** the created _.property style callback returns the property value of the given element. 
> 
> If a value is also provided for thisArg the created _.matchesProperty style callback returns true for elements that have a matching property value, else false. 
> 
> If an object is provided for **predicate** the created _.matches style callback returns true for elements that have the properties of the given object, else false.

I'm actually not quite sure which one you want -- `iteratee` or `predicate`. Can you clarify the difference between these two notions a little bit?

title: why _.sum cannot be called with iteratee?
body:
Hi, I like that some math methods are added, but I found that `_.sum` doesn't expect iteratee function as the 2nd argument.

``` js
_.sum([{a:1}, {a:2}], 'a') // I expected 3 but got 0
```

Is there any reason?
Thanks.

title: More descriptive readme and website
body:
The readme doesn't tell much about what lodash can do. It can be very helpful for people that just discovered lodash to have a list of features.

Also, as lodash is becoming more popular than underscore, we shouldn't asume that people know what underscore is in the website. Instead of saying "Features not in Underscore" we can say "Features in lodash" and then highlight in some way the ones that are lodash exclusive.

I can help with this, but my english is not very good.

Thank you for the excellent library!

title: Simpler but longer function names for FP newbies
body:
> Programs must be written for people to read, and only incidentally for machines to execute. 
> [(c)](http://www.goodreads.com/quotes/9168-programs-must-be-written-for-people-to-read-and-only)

And

> There are two hard things in computer science: cache invalidation, naming things, and off-by-one errors.
> [(c)](http://www.randomprogramming.com/2014/09/quote-of-the-week-hard-things/)

I know most of the lodash function names are well known functional style names. Although, lodash has about 300 functions. Remembering what they do is kind of hard. I keep lodash docs website opened without closing it for few months already.

Trying to teach a student I always find that it's really hard for them to remember what some of the lodash functions purpose is. Map and reduce names is something people can remember. It's good you introduced new `all` and `any` aliases. But there are few very short misleading names. Especially for newbies.

Examples. (It's just a quick list. I did not think about the names much.)

Array:
- `_.rest` -> the better name would be `_.allButFirst`.
- `_.zipObject` -> `_.composeObject`.
- `_.reject` -> `_.allBut` or/and `_.filterNot`.
- `_.sample` -> `_.pickRandom`.
- `_.after` and `_.before` -> `_.invokeAfter` or `_.callBefore`.
- `_.ary` -> confusing as hell. `_.acceptMaxArgsNumber`. Yeah, a very long one.
- `_.bindKey` -> `_.bindObjectFuncToArgs`
- `_.curry` -> `_.waitAllArgs`.
- `_.flow` -> too generic name. `_.invokeSequential` or kind of would be more clear.
- `_.momoize` -> `_.cacheCallResult`.
- `_.once` -> `_.invokeOnce`.
- `_.rearg` -> `_.rearrangeArguments`.
- `_.functions` -> `_.getObjectFunctions`.
- `_.invert` -> `_.invertKeysWithValues`.
- `_.keys` -> would be good to have alias `_.ownKeys`. Same for `_.ownValues`.
- `_.keysIn` -> same reasoning, `_.allKeys`. Same for `_.allValues`.
- `_.mapValue` -> this one is very clear actually. I wish all the rest were like it.
- `_.omit` -> `_.cloneExcept`.
- `_.pick` -> `_.cloneOnly`.
- `_.pair` -> `_.keyValuePairs`.
- `_.attempt` -> `_.getResultOrException`.

I understand that JS code doesn't like long names because traffic and typos. Although, people do better (functional) programming when function names do not allow many interpretations.

I am looking for a way to solve this issue. Any ideas?

P.S. I understand that I can create and maintain a separate module like "lodash-long-names". `require('lodash-long-names').assignAliases(_);`. Although, I think it's better to keep lodash activities under the same brilliant umbrella of @jdalton.

title: Add an example of the alternative zipObject syntax
body:
I usually glance at the examples before the actual blurb, and a number of times I've assumed zipObject doesn't do what I need because there's no example.

This is a tiny doc change to add an example of the two dimensional array usage.

title: Micro Optimisation - Ternary Operator
body:
Turn plus ternary operator into bitwise or operator. This is slightly faster;
See http://jsperf.com/parseint-vs-unary-plus

title: Should there be a difference between _([1,2,3]).each(function(){}) and _.each([1,2,3], function(){})?
_.pluck not working with maps
_.difference returns values to exclude when provided with undefined as first param
body:
```
_.difference(undefined, [1])
[1]
_.difference([1], undefined)
[1]
_.difference([], [1])
[]
_.difference([1], [2])
[1]
_.difference([2], [1])
[2]
```

I would've expected the first call to return an empty array. It's easy to miss a conditional or an or to coerce an undefined value to an empty array.

title: Using the `_.property` callback shorthand with `_.difference`
body:
``` javascript
var diff = _.difference(array1, array2, 'id');
```

Is it possible (doesn't seems so from the docs/source). If not, is it intentional not provided or just a missing feature. If so, I'll make a PR.
